elements.name: panel1
elements.title: What are your motives for founding a company?

elements.name: question1
elements.title: a) a general partnership?
elements.correctAnswer: This form of company focuses on the personal cooperation of the partners. This promotes the sense of responsibility and initiative of each partner. The division of labor (all partners - with the exception of the limited partner - are involved in the management), the easier procurement of capital compared to a sole proprietorship and the improved creditworthiness are advantageous, and the distribution of risk is also more favorable.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: b) a limited partnership?
elements.correctAnswer: The limited partnership is an extended form of the general partnership and enables the additional admission of investors.

elements.name: panel2
elements.title: What are your motives for founding a company?

elements.name: question3
elements.title: c) an AG?
elements.correctAnswer:
In the case of corporations, the focus is generally on financial participation (no shareholder involvement). The public limited company is particularly widespread; there are around 120,000 public limited companies in Switzerland. Reasons for popularity: 
- Raising capital: as several people can participate, it is easier to raise capital. 
- Liability: Liability is limited to the participation (no private liability), i.e. you only risk your invested capital. 
- Anonymity: The names of the partners are not published (in contrast to partnerships). 
- Succession regulation: The continued existence of the company is ensured by the fact that the company continues to exist regardless of any changes in shareholders. 
- Value-based mobilization of capital: The shares are tradable, possibly even marketable, and allow the owner to quickly dispose of an investment. 
The higher tax burden has a disadvantageous effect.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: d) a cooperative?
elements.correctAnswer: A cooperative is an association of at least seven cooperative members that is founded with the aim of offering its members economic self-help. The purpose of this form of enterprise is not to make a profit, but to provide benefits for the members of the cooperative.
